Getting Started¶

Last Updated: August 23, 2013

This tutorial is provided to help you get started using GsshaPy. In this tutorial you will learn important GsshaPy concepts and how to:

  • Read Files to a Database
  • Query using GsshaPy Objects
  • Write Files from a Database
  • Read and Write Entire GSSHA Projects

The full tutorial script can be downloaded here: tutorial-script.py

Requirements¶

Download the example GSSHA model files here: tutorial-data.zip.

Unzip the contents of the file. This file will become the working directory for the tutorial. The write and db directories are purposely left empty.

The tutorial uses an SQLite database. Ensure that you have SQLite installed on your system. Visit the SQLite webpage for download and installation instructions. Windows users ensure that the sqlite executable is added to your path.

Warning

GSSHAPY was only tested with SQLite3.

Key Concepts¶

The key abstraction of GsshaPy is the GSSHA model file. Most GSSHA model files are text files and many of them use a card system for assigning model parameters. Some of the files are GRASS ASCII maps and some of the data in other files are spatial in nature (though not in a standard format like a shp file).

The files that are supported are represented in GsshaPy by classes. There are two types of classes that have been defined in GsshaPy: file classes and table classes. All of the file classes inherit from a base file class called GsshaPyFileObjectBase. This class defines the read() and write() methods that are used to read the file into an SQL database.

Most file classes are supported with one or more table classes. Both the file classes and their supporting table classes inherit from the SQLAlchemy declarative base class. Declarative base maps each class to a table in the database, among other things. The properties of the file and table classes define the columns and relationships of the tables in the database. Instances of these classes represent records in these tables.

In most cases, a majority of the information in each file is stored in the database tables associated with the supporting table classes. The file class read() and write() methods orchestrate the reading and writing of data using the supporting table classes.

See also

For an explanation of the SQLAlchemy ORM see http://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/rel_0_8/orm/tutorial.html. If you are not familiar with SQLAlchemy, it strongly recommended that you follow this tutorial before you continue, because GsshaPy relies heavily on SQLAlchemy ORM concepts.
